subject: Ethics
title: Tragedy of the Commons in Action
description: A micro-lesson that makes Tragedy of the Commons in Action usable.

hook.text: A shared pasture feeds every farmer's cattle perfectlyâ€”until one farmer adds an extra cow.

buildup.text: Garrett Hardin's 1968 'Tragedy of the Commons' argued that shared resources inevitably get overused.

discovery.text: Each individual gains from taking more, but the collective cost is shared. Rational choices add up to ruin.

twist.text: Elinor Ostrom won a Nobel Prize proving Hardin wrongâ€”communities can self-govern shared resources successfully.

climax.text: The real tragedy isn't sharing. It's assuming people can't cooperate without privatization or government force.

punchline.text: The commons don't fail. Our rules for managing them do.

quiz.question: How did Elinor Ostrom challenge Garrett Hardin's 'Tragedy of the Commons'?
options: She showed communities can successfully self-govern shared resources
She proved all commons should be privatized
She argued the tragedy only applies to water resources
